name: punica-granatum
wildlife-value: The brilliant flowers are very attractive to hummingbirds.
edibility: Juice from seeeds high in potassium and vitamin C and other antioxidants.  Select a fruit that is heavy for the size and does not have cracks or splits. Pomegranates are hand-harvested at peak ripeness. Store whole fruit at room temperature for a few days or place in the refrigerator in plastic bags for up to 3 months.  Arils can also be refrigerated or frozen in a single layer than placed in bags in the freezer for a quick snack later.  Grenadine is a red syrup used to flavor beverages that is made from pomegranate seeds.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description:
This fruit is usually about the size of a large orange 2"-4" in diameter.  Once the leathery outer skin is removed, hundreds of red “seeds” are revealed.  Although we may call these little fruit “seeds”, they are botanically known as arils.  An aril is a fleshy, juicy, brightly colored tissue, which covers the actual seed.
2 to 3.5 in. edible fruit in fall; thick rind, seedy and tart
flower-description: 1 in. orange, red, pink, yellow, or white flowers 1 1/4" wide with crepe paper-like petals cluster at the ends of branches in early summer to fall.
leaf-description: Alternate, opposite or whorled lustrous dark green leaves; 1 to 4 in. long; yellow-green fall color
uses: Traditionally it was used medicinally to treat disorders of the ciruclartory system. Native Americans also used the blossoms in jewelry making.
